--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@a...> 
wrote:
>=
 Open questions:
> 
>   - This process will usually involve revisiting the =
exact
>     same URI, with different headers or POST data that
>     result=
s in different content returned. Such revisits
>     can easily be stored i=
n ARC files but may confuse some
>     post-crawl reporting and access prac=
tices.
> 
>   - Request-headers (including HTTP-authentication or
>     coo=
kies) and POST data are not currently stored in
>     ARC files, but may be=
 necessary for understanding the
>     (different) results returned. The AR=
C format must
>     be extended soon.
> 

Here is a proposal for an extensi=
on of the arc format in order to 
accommodate more detailed metadata. 

An =
entry for a http response currently looks like this in the ARC 
format usin=
g the url-record-v1 format:

http://<url1> <ip1> <timestamp1> <mime-type1> =
<data-size1>
<DATA1 =96 http header, response data>

When data are collecte=
d using the HTTP post method ambiguities may 
arise as multiple requests fo=
r different web pages may be represented 
by the same url. An additional he=
ader field is proposed added to the 
ARC header to resolve these ambiguitie=
s. 

http://<url1> <ip1> <timestamp1> <mime-type1> 
<data-size1> <request-e=
ncoding1>
<DATA1 =96 http header, response data>

The new field request-enc=
oding is an MD5 checksum created from the 
http request. This encoding can =
be used to distinguish between 
different post requests. Notice that only a=
 relevant subset of the 
complete http request should be used to create the=
 checksum. This 
subset must include the url, the message body, and possibl=
y the 
authentication information and cookie values. We do not want to 
inc=
lude fields such as Accept, Referrer, Host and User-Agent as they 
do not d=
efine the content of the requested page.

This format still lacks detailed =
information about the http request 
header and does not provide means to ad=
d additional meta-data 
information. It is proposed that additional meta-da=
ta information is 
stored using the format:

metadata:http://<url2> <ip2> <=
timestamp2> text/xml 
<data size2> <request-encoding2>
<DATA2 =96 metadata =
for url>

Where 
<url1>=3D<url2>
<ip1> =3D <ip2>
<timestamp1> =3D <timestam=
p2>
<request-encoding1>=3D<request-encoding2>


The DATA2 section is an xml=
 representation of various metadata 
available during collection of the url=
 object. This information must 
as a minimum contain the complete http requ=
est. 




>   - When it does become possible to record the outgoing
>     a=
uth/form info, there may be reasons that it should
>     be left out (or di=
rected to a file separate from the
>     main archives) -- for example if i=
t utilizes login
>     info which must be kept secret. In some cases,
>    =
 leakage of such secret info may be very difficult
>     to prevent, if the=
 website echoes back login info
>     in plaintext-equivalent forms in cook=
ies or hidden
>     form variables.

> - Gordon
